articles.headline: If Customers Have to Pay for Checking, They Should Be Consoled With Perks
articles.snippet: One great feature is the ability to deposit checks with a smartphone, but few banks offer the service.
articles.abstract: One great feature is the ability to deposit checks with a smartphone, but few banks offer the service.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks want many of us to start paying monthly fees again for our checking accounts. So why won’t they give us something worth paying for?

articles.headline: Bank Losses Lead to Drop in Credit Card Debt
articles.snippet: Billions in charges written off by banks could have more to do with a decline in credit card debt than the frugality of struggling consumers.
articles.abstract: Billions in charges written off by banks could have more to do with a decline in credit card debt than the frugality of struggling consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The substantial drop in credit card debt in the United States since early 2009 has been widely attributed to newly frugal consumers. But analysts say that a significant portion of the decline is actually the result of financial institutions writing off billions of dollars in credit card debt as losses.

articles.headline: Widespread Fraud Seen in Latest Afghan Elections
articles.snippet: Evidence is mounting that fraud in Afghan election last weekend was so widespread that it could affect the results in a third of provinces.
articles.abstract: Evidence is mounting that fraud in Afghan election last weekend was so widespread that it could affect the results in a third of provinces.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Evidence is mounting that fraud in last weekend’s parliamentary election was so widespread that it could affect the results in a third of provinces, calling into question the credibility of a vote that was an important test of the American and Afghan effort to build a stable and legitimate government.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Carlotta Gall

articles.headline: Regulators Step in to Aid Credit Unions
articles.snippet: Regulators took over three financial institutions that provide the underpinning for hundreds of the nation’s credit unions.
articles.abstract: Regulators took over three financial institutions that provide the underpinning for hundreds of the nation’s credit unions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly two years after Wall Street’s giants were rescued by the federal government, regulators on Friday took over three financial institutions that provide the underpinning for hundreds of the nation’s credit unions.

articles.headline: A Billionaire Army of One vs. a Bank
articles.snippet: The investor Len Blavatnik is fighting in court to get back some of the money he lost because of what he calls bank negligence.
articles.abstract: The investor Len Blavatnik is fighting in court to get back some of the money he lost because of what he calls bank negligence.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I was pitched a seemingly irresistible story about an investor who had been wronged by JPMorgan Chase during the financial crisis. The investor, Len Blavatnik, was now fighting in court to get back some of the money he had lost because of the bank’s alleged negligence.

articles.headline: Stepping Down, NBC Chief Relishes His Long Tenure
articles.snippet: Jeff Zucker, chief of NBC Universal, announced Friday that he would step down upon the completion of the takeover of NBC by Comcast.
articles.abstract: Jeff Zucker, chief of NBC Universal, announced Friday that he would step down upon the completion of the takeover of NBC by Comcast.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal and the longest-serving senior manager at NBC Universal, announced Friday that he would step down upon the completion of the takeover of NBC by Comcast.

articles.headline: GMAC’s Errors Leave Foreclosures in Question
articles.snippet: The lender’s admission that it had filed dubious foreclosure documents could inspire a broad legal furor against hasty foreclosures.
articles.abstract: The lender’s admission that it had filed dubious foreclosure documents could inspire a broad legal furor against hasty foreclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The recent admission by a major mortgage lender that it had filed dubious foreclosure documents is likely to fuel a furor against hasty foreclosures, which have prompted complaints nationwide since housing prices collapsed.

articles.headline: Voters Moving to Oust Judges Over Decisions
articles.snippet: Judicial elections that were designed to be as apolitical as possible are suddenly as contentious as any another race.
articles.abstract: Judicial elections that were designed to be as apolitical as possible are suddenly as contentious as any another race.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES  After the State Supreme Court here stunned the nation by making this the first state in the heartland to allow same-sex marriage, Iowa braced for its sleepy judicial elections to turn into referendums on gay marriage.

articles.headline: Gas Blasts Spur Questions on Oversight
articles.snippet: Experts say that weak oversight of the 2.7 million miles of gas pipeline in the United States has contributed to hundreds of episodes that have killed 60 people in the last five years.
articles.abstract: Experts say that weak oversight of the 2.7 million miles of gas pipeline in the United States has contributed to hundreds of episodes that have killed 60 people in the last five years.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a Christmas Eve gathering in 2008, a natural gas explosion in a suburban Sacramento neighborhood killed a 72-year-old man and injured his daughter and granddaughter. Investigators determined that Pacific Gas and Electric was to blame for a leak, but federal and state regulators never cited the utility for safety violations.

articles.headline: U.S. Gift for Iraqis Offers a Primer on Corruption
articles.snippet: A shipment of computer laptops to Iraq was part of the American military’s mission to win hearts and minds, but the good intentions were mugged by Iraq’s reality.
articles.abstract: A shipment of computer laptops to Iraq was part of the American military’s mission to win hearts and minds, but the good intentions were mugged by Iraq’s reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The shipment of laptop computers that arrived in Iraq’s main seaport in February was a small but important part of the American military’s mission here to win hearts and minds. What happened afterward is a tale of good intentions mugged by Iraq’s reality.

articles.headline: Sex Scandal Threatens a Georgia Pastor’s Empire
articles.snippet: Four former members of a youth group run by Bishop Eddie L. Long have accused him of coercing them into sex acts, and of abusing his moral authority.
articles.abstract: Four former members of a youth group run by Bishop Eddie L. Long have accused him of coercing them into sex acts, and of abusing his moral authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: LITHONIA, Ga.  Over the last two decades, Bishop Eddie L. Long has built a religious and financial empire from scratch, transforming a small, faltering church into a modern cathedral with one of the largest and most influential congregations in the country.
articles.byline: By JAMES C. McKINLEY and ROBBIE BROWN

articles.headline: Can We Build in a Brighter Shade of Green?
articles.snippet: Advocates of the passive-house standard for home design say it could greatly improve on America’s drafty houses. But it has caught on only in Europe.
articles.abstract: Advocates of the passive-house standard for home design say it could greatly improve on America’s drafty houses. But it has caught on only in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORWICH, Vt.

articles.headline: Questions, and Directors, Lost in the Ether
articles.snippet: With online annual meetings, companies may have an easier time dismissing shareholder concerns.
articles.abstract: With online annual meetings, companies may have an easier time dismissing shareholder concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANNUAL shareholder meetings may not be the most efficient occasion for managers to meet with the owners of the companies they run  they can be hard for shareholders to get to and are sometimes hijacked by gadflies with personal agendas and long-winded, irrelevant questions. Because most, if not all, shareholders cast their votes before the meetings even take place, they can feel ritualistic and not terribly meaningful.

articles.headline: In This War, Movie Studios Are Siding With Your Couch
articles.snippet: Armed with new copy-blocking technology, studios want to offer new movies on video-on-demand only about 45 days after they arrive in theaters, at a premium price.
articles.abstract: Armed with new copy-blocking technology, studios want to offer new movies on video-on-demand only about 45 days after they arrive in theaters, at a premium price.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

articles.headline: Democrats Unleash Ads Focusing on Rivals’ Pasts
articles.snippet: Many Democrats are deploying the fruits of a yearlong investigation into the business and personal histories of Republican candidates in an effort to plant doubts about them.
articles.abstract: Many Democrats are deploying the fruits of a yearlong investigation into the business and personal histories of Republican candidates in an effort to plant doubts about them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Democratic candidates across the country are opening a fierce offensive of negative advertisements against Republicans, using lawsuits, tax filings, reports from the Better Business Bureau and even divorce proceedings to try to discredit their opponents and save their Congressional majority.

articles.headline: Rove Returns, With Team, Planning G.O.P. Push
articles.snippet: The master Republican strategist Karl Rove is marshaling the resources of disparate business, nonprofit and interest groups to bring Republicans back to power.
articles.abstract: The master Republican strategist Karl Rove is marshaling the resources of disparate business, nonprofit and interest groups to bring Republicans back to power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In 2004, the Republican master strategist Karl Rove led weekly sessions at his Washington residence where, over big plates of his butter-smothered “eggies” and bacon slabs, he planned the re-election of President George W. Bush  and what he hoped would be lasting Republican dominion over Democrats.

articles.headline: U.S. Scrambling to Save Talks on Middle East
articles.snippet: As Israel’s freeze on Jewish settlement building in the West Bank ended, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asked President Mahmoud Abbas to continue negotiations.
articles.abstract: As Israel’s freeze on Jewish settlement building in the West Bank ended, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asked President Mahmoud Abbas to continue negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Israel allowed a politically charged freeze on Jewish settlement building in the West Bank to expire on Sunday, but the Palestinians did not carry out a threat to quit peace negotiations, setting the stage for further frantic efforts to keep the talks alive.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Nokia’s New Chief Faces Culture of Complacency
articles.snippet: As Stephen Elop takes over at Nokia, he must regain its lost ground in smartphones and maintain its dominance as the largest maker of mobile phones.
articles.abstract: As Stephen Elop takes over at Nokia, he must regain its lost ground in smartphones and maintain its dominance as the largest maker of mobile phones.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years before Apple introduced the iPhone, research engineers at Nokia prepared a prototype of an Internet-ready, touch-screen handset with a large display, which they thought could give the company a powerful advantage in the fast-growing smartphone market.

articles.headline: Anger as a Private Company Takes Over Libraries
articles.snippet: Library Systems & Services was hired to run the libraries of Santa Clarita, Calif., setting off an outsourcing debate.
articles.abstract: Library Systems & Services was hired to run the libraries of Santa Clarita, Calif., setting off an outsourcing debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARITA, Calif.  A private company in Maryland has taken over public libraries in ailing cities in California, Oregon, Tennessee and Texas, growing into the country’s fifth-largest library system.

articles.headline: New Team Alters Disney Studios’ Path
articles.snippet: The kinds of movies Disney makes have changed, and it has recruited some top new directors.
articles.abstract: The kinds of movies Disney makes have changed, and it has recruited some top new directors.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  When you spend 38 years producing movies, as Jerry Bruckheimer has, you see studio regimes come and go  out with the old, in with the new. The circumstances differ, but one aspect, he said, is always the same: “Hollywood kills you when you bring in an outsider.”

articles.headline: Wage Laws Squeeze South Africa’s Poor
articles.snippet: With one third of South Africans jobless, a crackdown on minimum wage violations has been met with protest — from workers.
articles.abstract: With one third of South Africans jobless, a crackdown on minimum wage violations has been met with protest — from workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWCASTLE, South Africa — The sheriff arrived at the factory here to shut it down, part of a national enforcement drive against clothing manufacturers who violate the minimum wage. But women working on the factory floor — the supposed beneficiaries of the crackdown — clambered atop cutting tables and ironing boards to raise anguished cries against it.

articles.headline: Comcast Spends Big in Pressing for Merger
articles.snippet: Comcast has poured out its piggy bank in Washington to see through its merger with NBC Universal, spending tens of millions of dollars on lobbyists, gifts, ads and investments.
articles.abstract: Comcast has poured out its piggy bank in Washington to see through its merger with NBC Universal, spending tens of millions of dollars on lobbyists, gifts, ads and investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Jeff Zucker’s announcement on Friday that he was stepping aside as the head of NBC Universal, Comcast’s purchase of the company was taken almost as a fait accompli.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Tim Arango

articles.headline: China Imposes a Steep Tariff on U.S. Poultry
articles.snippet: The poultry tariffs are another example of China’s willingness to use its economic leverage when it feels it is being challenged.
articles.abstract: The poultry tariffs are another example of China’s willingness to use its economic leverage when it feels it is being challenged.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Days after it flexed its economic muscle in a diplomatic dispute with Japan, China continued to display a more assertive international economic policy on Sunday as it imposed steep tariffs on poultry imports from the United States.

articles.headline: Shifting Online, Netflix Faces New Competition
articles.snippet: As more consumers stream movies and television, Netflix faces a number of well-financed and innovative companies like Apple, Amazon and Google.
articles.abstract: As more consumers stream movies and television, Netflix faces a number of well-financed and innovative companies like Apple, Amazon and Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Even though Netflix’s arch rival Blockbuster has filed for bankruptcy protection, the victory lap will have to wait. The company that filled American mailboxes with red envelopes containing DVDs is already fighting the next war.

articles.headline: Raters Ignored Proof of Unsafe Loans, Panel Is Told
articles.snippet: Agencies that assessed risk in mortgage pools dismissed evidence of dubious loans, according to testimony.
articles.abstract: Agencies that assessed risk in mortgage pools dismissed evidence of dubious loans, according to testimony.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the mortgage market grew frothy in 2006  leading to a housing bubble that nearly brought down the banking system two years later  ratings agencies charged with assessing risk in mortgage pools dismissed conclusive evidence that many of the loans were dubious, according to testimony given last week to the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission.

articles.headline: U.S. Tries to Make It Easier to Wiretap the Internet
articles.snippet: Officials are preparing to seek sweeping new regulations, arguing they are losing their capability to track suspects.
articles.abstract: Officials are preparing to seek sweeping new regulations, arguing they are losing their capability to track suspects.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Federal law enforcement and national security officials are preparing to seek sweeping new regulations for the Internet, arguing that their ability to wiretap criminal and terrorism suspects is “going dark” as people increasingly communicate online instead of by telephone.

articles.headline: Southwest, Determined to Expand, Buys AirTran
articles.snippet: The $1.4 billion deal increases Southwest’s foothold in New York and Boston and allows it to move into Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International, the nation’s largest airport.
articles.abstract: The $1.4 billion deal increases Southwest’s foothold in New York and Boston and allows it to move into Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International, the nation’s largest airport.
articles.lead_paragraph: The merger fever in the airline business is showing no signs of abating.
